body: ARCHERY World Champions MEN'S OLYMPIC BOW Andrea Parenti, Italy. WOMEN'S OLYMPIC BOW Carole Ferriou, France. MEN'S COMPOUND BOW Jeff Button, Cottage Grove, Wis. title: From Atlanta To Wembley, Winners All

body: YESTERDAY,'' sang the elderly woman in a long frilly dress. ''Yesterday.'' Her voice echoed through a ballroom in Brooklyn where two dozen members of the Senior League of Flatbush sat listening. Suddenly she stopped, flustered. ''I can't remember the words,'' she said, shaking her head. But she was not easily defeated. After burrowing among papers,
title: Centers for Elderly Enter a New Age

body: Kathryn Falk, the self-styled Queen of Romance, looked decidedly unromantic on a recent morning in Brooklyn, swigging cough syrup from the bottle and padding about her romance-magazine offices in Kmart slippers. She gave a visitor a quick tour of Romantic Times Magazine, from her display of erotic Chinese silk shoes -- a few inches long, for bound
title: A Magazine for Romance Novels And the Women Who Love Them

author: David Willis McCullough's books include ''Brooklyn . . . And How It Got That Way'' and the mystery novel ''Point No-Point.''
body: Whatever happened to the know-it-all travel book? Handy guides to every imaginable backwater continue to flourish, telling what's open when, and where to find a decent -- or not so decent -- hotel. And reporters home from foreign assignments still check in with highly perishable accounts of what they've just learned abroad. But where are those
title: Travel

body: To the Editor: Ms. Ravitch's efforts to improve public education would produce greater results if she were to study the quality management profession's approach to the issue. I invite Ms. Ravitch to investigate this ''whole systems'' approach, as detailed in the landmark book ''Thinking for a Living: Education and the Wealth of Nations,'' by Ray
title: Article Misstated Views On Multicultural Education

body: To the Editor: I read with great interest ''Etiquette: Is It Back?'' (Sept. 22) and have sorrowfully concluded that it is not. Etiquette will continue to be the Jimmy Hoffa of belief systems for as long as your publication endorses the notion that French fries, asparagus and shrimp are hand foods. I find these suggestions vulgar in the extreme and
title: French Fries as Hand Food? Perish the Thought!

body: To The Editor: Your fine piece on driving instructors (''Driver's Ed, Where Driving Is a Blood Sport,'' Sept. 8) brought back memories of Mary Cacae, owner/chief instructor of the Park Circle Driving School in Brooklyn (motto: ''Drive in the Circle of Confidence''). A few months before my wedding in 1982, it was time to get a driver's license. I
title: A Good Driving Instructor Made Surprise Appearance

body: Only 20 years ago, New York City had schoolrooms to spare. From 1975 to 1982, nearly 100 schools were given away, sold off, left vacant, turned into administrative offices, torn down. At that time, when city planners saw the number of schoolchildren decreasing and the city's fiscal crisis simmering, the decision to close schools seemed to make
title: Roots of School Overcrowding Stretch Back Two Decades

body: The Father of Chinantla has no doorbell, but then he is rarely at home. The easiest way to find the elder statesman of ''La Quince,'' as the Mexicans who live on and around 15th Avenue call their neighborhood, is to pop into a bodega on 36th Street and say, ''Margarito?'' When the inquiry was made one recent evening, the response from the clerk was
title: Far From His Mexican Town, He's Still the Town Father

body: Fashion Clinic Alice Austen House 2 Hylan Boulevard, Rosebank, S.I. Recommended ages: 9 to 12 Tomorrow Everyone should have a house like Alice's. This Victorian beachside cottage overlooking New York Harbor was built in 1690, but Alice Austen didn't arrive until 1866. She was a photographer, and she lived there through 1945. Her former home will be
title: For Children

body: There are no brownstones in Bangladesh. But in the brownstone corridors of Brooklyn, the men who wipe grime off the aging stone buildings, restore their cracking stoops and spruce up their cornices are increasingly immigrants from Bangladesh. Sometimes, people ask, 'Where did you learn to do this?' " said Mostafizur Rahman, a construction worker
title: Building Lives on Brooklyn's Scaffolds

body: Jillur Rahman has spent five years in his brick house in Midwood, Brooklyn, long enough to know every face on his block and for his 4-year-old son to know no other home. So he was devastated when he received the call from his former landlord telling him that he would have to move and that a judge would decide how soon. What do you say?" Mr. Rahman
title: Bank's Good-Neighbor Efforts Yield Some Unwanted Returns;Risky Mortgages Force Eviction of Paying Tenants

body: In a citywide crackdown on illegal fireworks, the police have so far seized more than 1,600 cases and arrested 49 people, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday. On Friday night, he said, the police confiscated 225 cases of fireworks, several guns and boxes of ammunition at a house in Brooklyn. The raid Friday, by the police and
title: 49 Are Arrested in Fireworks Crackdown

body: Long ago, before the world turned upside down, there existed a Europe where civilized people could sip afternoon coffee, eat fine pastries and listen to music. Then came the Holocaust and lives, families and hope were ripped apart. More than half a century has passed since the liberation of the concentration camps. Many came to America to build new
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MIDWOOD;For Survivors, Kaffeeklatshes Open a Window to Old World

body: KATHERINE MATHEWS, a physician in her 30's, got so piqued one night at the recalcitrant pony she was riding -- a filly by the name of Bo-Peep -- that she did something she never expected to do. When her riding teacher changed her over to a full-size horse and said, "Canter," she accomplished the gait like a dream, with unerring mastery and perfect
title: The Long, Scary Road to the Bridle Path

title: City Is Safer, Rising Number Of People Say;Attitudes Catching Up To 2-Year Fall in Crime
